sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Gonorrhea: (uncomplicated cervical, urethral, and rectal infections) 2 g IM administered with probenecid 1 g ORALLY plus either a single dose of azithromycin 1 g ORALLY or doxycycline 100 mg ORALLY twice daily for 7 days (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used
  • Infectious disease of abdomen: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infectious disease of abdomen: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: 2 g IV every 6 hours plus doxycycline 100 mg ORALLY or IV every 12 hours; continue for at least 24 hours after clinical improvement with oral doxycycline continued for a total of 14 days; OR 2 g IM as a single dose with probenecid 1 g ORALLY as a single dose plus doxycycline 100 mg ORALLY twice daily for 14 days with or without metronidazole 500 mg ORALLY twice daily for 14 days (guideline dosing)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used (manufacturer dosing)
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis: 2 g IV, 30 to 60 minutes prior to surgery followed by 2 g IV every 6 hours for a total of 24 hours
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis: CESAREAN SECTION: 2 g IV as soon as umbilical cord is clamped with or without 2 g every 4 hours for 2 doses
  • Septicemia: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: uncomplicated infection: 1 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: moderate to severe infection: 1 g IV every 4 hours OR 2 g IV every 6 to 8 hours depending on type and severity of infection, doses up to 2 g IV every 4 hours OR 3 g IV every 6 hours have been used

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal insufficiency (adults): give initial loading dose of 1 to 2 g IV; CrCl 30 to 50 mL/min, 1 to 2 g every 8 to 12 hr; CrCl 10 to 29 mL/min, 1 to 2 g every 12 to 24 hr; CrCl 5 to 9 mL/min, 0.5 to 1 g every 12 to 24 hr; CrCl less than 5 mL/min, 0.5 to 1 g every 24 to 48 hr
  • renal insufficiency (pediatric patients): modify dose and frequency consistent with adult recommendations

sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to penicillins
  • gastrointestinal disease, particularly colitis, history
  • urine output reduced due to renal insufficiency, transient or persistent; may result in high and prolonged serum antibiotic concentrations; consider dose reduction

sub.mono:

  • Cefoxitin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Cefoxitin sodium is a bactericidal semi-synthetic, broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic. It inhibits cell wall synthesis and is active against gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. It is highly resistant to beta-lactamases of gram-negative bacteria (both penicillinases and cephalosporinases) due to a methoxy group in its 7-alpha position.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 41 min to 59 min
  • geriatrics: 51 min to 90 min

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • a 1 g vial should be reconstituted with 10 mL, or a 2 g vial with 10 or 20 mL, Sterile Water for Injection, Bacteriostatic Water for Injection, NS, or D5W.
  • (bolus) 1 gram or 2 grams in 10 mL of Sterile Water for Injection can be injected over a period of 3 to 5 min, either directly or through an existing IV line
  • (infusion) reconstituted vials may be further diluted in 50 to 100 mL of NS, D5W, or D10W Injection

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion of large doses of cephalosporins may result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Seizures have developed after parenteral overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may commonly occur with therapy; oral exposures are less likely to cause severe allergic reactions than parenteral exposures. Seizures have also been reported following therapeutic administration. Prolonged prothrombin times, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathies associated with a qualitative platelet defect and aggregation abnormalities have been reported following IV cephalosporin therapy. Pseudocholelithiasis may follow intravenous administration of ceftriaxone. Several cases of fatal hemolytic reactions following intravenous ceftriaxone therapy have been reported in children with serious hematologic abnormalities.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
  • Decontamination: Generally not indicated in patients with no underlying health problems. Activated charcoal may be necessary for patients with underlying renal insufficiency.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor renal function, electrolytes, CBC including platelets.
  • Anaphylaxis: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULTS: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILDREN: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Blood coagulation disorder: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma
  • Intrathecal injection: Treat seizures with anticonvulsants (benzodiazepines, propofol, phenobarbital); endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers). For large overdoses, consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes 80 to 150 mL/hr). Dexamethasone 4 mg intravenously every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
TOXICITY: Serious toxicity is unlikely following large oral doses of cephalosporins. Crystalluria and hematuria has been described in a 3-year-old boy who ingested 104 mg/kg of cephalexin. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. CEPHALEXIN: CHILDREN: 25 to 100 milligrams/kilogram/24 hours orally, up to a maximum of 4 grams/day, divided every 6 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Advise patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine. Other superinfection signs/symptoms should be reported as well.
